queries.company_overview:
What it does: Qualcomm designs and sells Snapdragon semiconductor platforms for mobile, automotive, IoT and PCs, and licenses its cellular IP portfolio globally through QTL.
Main business units / segments:
- QCT (Qualcomm CDMA Technologies): chipsets/platforms for Handsets, Automotive, IoT, and Windows-on-Arm PCs
- QTL (Qualcomm Technology Licensing): licensing of 3G/4G/5G SEPs and related IP
- QSI (Qualcomm Strategic Initiatives): strategic investments and incubation (non-reportable)
High-level financials: FY2024 (year ended 2024-09-29) GAAP revenue $39.0B; GAAP net income $10.1B; Market capitalization $186.5B (as of 2025-11-05).
Competitive positioning: Qualcomm is a leading supplier of premium-tier Android SoCs and 5G modems and a major licensor of cellular IP. It competes with MediaTek (smartphone SoCs), Apple and Samsung (in-house silicon), Broadcom/Skyworks/Qorvo (RF/connectivity), and Nvidia/AMD/Intel/Apple in PCs and compute. In automotive digital cockpit/ADAS, competition includes Nvidia and Mobileye; Qualcomm’s design pipeline and partnerships underpin growing automotive share.
Recent major news:
- 2024-11-06 Qualcomm reports FY2024 GAAP revenue $39.0B and net income $10.1B; board approves new $15B share repurchase authorization.
- 2025-01-06 Qualcomm showcases AI innovations at CES 2025 and unveils Snapdragon X platform enabling $600 Copilot+ PCs.
- 2025-02-05 Q1 FY2025 results: revenue $11.7B and GAAP EPS $2.83; record QCT and Handsets quarterly revenues.
- 2025-03-18 Qualcomm increases quarterly cash dividend from $0.85 to $0.89 per share.
- 2025-09-30 U.S. court grants Qualcomm complete victory over Arm in licensing litigation.

What secured 3nm foundry capacity has Qu.query: What secured 3nm foundry capacity has Qualcomm booked at TSMC through 2026?
What secured 3nm foundry capacity has Qu.answer: Reports from Taiwan’s Economic Daily News indicate that Apple, Qualcomm, Nvidia, and AMD have effectively fully booked TSMC’s 3nm capacity, with customer queues extending into 2026. Qualcomm’s exact share of the secured capacity is not publicly disclosed, but TSMC is expanding N3 output to an estimated 120,000–180,000 wafers per month to meet demand.

search_results.title: 大客戶包下產能 訂單滿至2026 台積電3奈米掀搶購潮
search_results.snippet: Economic Daily News reports that major clients—Apple, Qualcomm, Nvidia, and AMD—have pre-booked TSMC’s 3nm family capacity, creating a queue that runs into 2026; to meet demand, TSMC is shifting some 5nm equipment to 3nm and aims to raise monthly N3 output to about 120,000–180,000 wafers.

search_results.title: Apple, Qualcomm, Nvidia, AMD fully book TSMC's 3nm capacity
search_results.snippet: Citing Economic Daily News, TechNode says Apple, Qualcomm, Nvidia, and AMD have almost fully booked TSMC’s 3nm process until 2026; TSMC’s N3 lineup (N3/N3E/N3P/N3X/N3A) is ramping, with plans to boost 3nm output to an estimated 120,000–180,000 wafers per month to satisfy demand.

search_results.title: TSMC's 3nm process production lines booked through 2026
search_results.snippet: TweakTown, referencing UDN, reports that Apple, AMD, Nvidia, and Qualcomm have signed major contracts that soak up TSMC’s 3nm capacity, with customer queues extending into 2026; N3E is in mass production and N3P is set to scale in H2 2024, underscoring tight 3nm supply.

Has Qualcomm extended its Apple 5G modem.query: Has Qualcomm extended its Apple 5G modem supply agreement beyond 2026?
Has Qualcomm extended its Apple 5G modem.answer: No. Qualcomm’s official supply agreement with Apple covers iPhone launches in 2024, 2025, and 2026, with no formal announcement extending chip supply beyond 2026. In January 2024, Qualcomm said Apple extended the separate patent licensing agreement to March 2027, but that licensing extension is distinct from the modem supply deal.

search_results.title: Qualcomm Announces Agreement with Apple for Chip Supply
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm’s press release states it will supply Snapdragon 5G Modem‑RF Systems for Apple smartphone launches in 2024, 2025 and 2026; it specifies supply through 2026 and does not announce any extension beyond that period.

search_results.title: Apple Extends Modem Licensing Deal With Qualcomm Through March 2027
search_results.snippet: On Qualcomm’s Q1 2024 call, the company said Apple exercised a unilateral option to extend their global patent license by two years to March 2027; this update concerns licensing, while the separate modem supply agreement had already been extended only through 2026.

search_results.title: Apple extends deal with Qualcomm for 5G modems until 2027
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm CEO Cristiano Amon said after Q1 2024 results that Qualcomm will continue to license its 5G modems to Apple until March 2027; previously, the companies’ modem supply deal covered iPhone launches in 2024–2026, with no formal supply extension beyond 2026 announced.

What is Qualcomm's 2025 shipment commitm.query: What is Qualcomm's 2025 shipment commitment for Snapdragon X PCs by OEM?
What is Qualcomm's 2025 shipment commitm.answer: Qualcomm has not published OEM-by-OEM shipment commitments for Snapdragon X PCs in 2025. Public disclosures focus on overall targets: roughly 80 Snapdragon X PC designs planned/launched in 2025 and 100+ by 2026, with devices from Acer, ASUS, Dell, HP, and Lenovo. Qualcomm also cited ~10% U.S. retail share (>$800 Windows PCs) but provided no per-OEM shipment breakdown.

search_results.title: Qualcomm claims it owns 10% of U.S. Windows PC retail market for devices priced $800 and up
search_results.snippet: Following Q1 FY2025 results, Qualcomm said Snapdragon X powers about 10% of U.S. Windows PCs priced $800+ and noted 80 PC designs planned/launched for 2025 with 100+ designs targeted through 2026. The company did not disclose OEM-specific shipment commitments.

search_results.title: Qualcomm: Snapdragon X Partner Program Is 'Hyper Competitive' Against Intel, AMD
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm executives said more than 85 Snapdragon-based PCs are available from OEMs like HP, Dell and Lenovo, with the total expected to surpass 100 next year. The discussion highlights overall design momentum and channel plans, without providing any 2025 shipment commitments by OEM.

search_results.title: Snapdragon X Series Continues to Redefine the PC Category with a New Platform, Mini Desktop Form Factors, and NPU-powered AI Experiences
search_results.snippet: At CES 2025, Qualcomm announced the entry-level Snapdragon X platform and said over 60 designs are in production or development, with devices from Acer, Asus, Dell, HP and Lenovo expected in early 2025. The release outlines OEM participation but does not include OEM-by-OEM shipment commitments.

What is Qualcomm's tape-out schedule for.query: What is Qualcomm's tape-out schedule for next-generation Oryon CPUs across mobile and PC?
What is Qualcomm's tape-out schedule for.answer: Qualcomm hasn’t published exact tape-out dates, but roadmaps and launch windows let us infer timing. For mobile, the third‑gen Oryon CPU debuted with Snapdragon 8 Elite Gen 5 announced on Sept 24, 2025 for the next wave of Android flagships, implying tape-out in early–mid 2025 on TSMC 3 nm. For PCs, Dell’s leaked XPS roadmap shows “QC Oryon V2” slated for H2 2025 (with products targeted for early 2026), and Qualcomm later confirmed Snapdragon X2 laptops ship in H1 2026—together pointing to a PC tape-out window in H2 2025; a further Oryon V3 generation aligns to late 2027.

search_results.title: Snapdragon X2 Elite Extreme: Qualcomm goes up to 18 cores and 5 GHz; notebooks in first half of 2026
search_results.snippet: At Snapdragon Summit 2025, Qualcomm outlined its next PC chips, stating that Snapdragon X2 Elite (Extreme) notebooks are planned to arrive in the first half of 2026. That timing places next‑gen Oryon for PCs on track for products in early 2026 after the fall 2025 reveal, implying fabrication milestones several months earlier.

search_results.title: Next-gen Arm Snapdragon X chips for PCs to arrive in 2025 — major Dell leak exposes Qualcomm's roadmap with ‘V2’ and ‘V3’ models
search_results.snippet: A leaked Dell XPS roadmap lists “QC Oryon V2” for H2 2025 and “QC Oryon V3” for late 2027; Dell expects to receive Snapdragon X Gen 2 in mid‑2025 and include it in products around January 2026. The slide provides a cadence for next‑gen Oryon PC CPUs, with sampling in mid‑2025 and productization in early 2026.

search_results.title: Qualcomm announces Snapdragon 8 Elite Gen 5
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm unveiled Snapdragon 8 Elite Gen 5 on Sept 24, 2025, built on a 3 nm node with third‑gen Oryon CPU cores to power the next generation of Android phones. With devices set to follow this launch window, the mobile Oryon refresh was readied earlier in 2025, consistent with tape-out months ahead of retail availability.

What percentage of Qualcomm's FY2025 rev.query: What percentage of Qualcomm's FY2025 revenue is exposed to China market demand?
What percentage of Qualcomm's FY2025 rev.answer: Roughly mid-40s percent. Qualcomm disclosed that about 46% of its most recent full-year revenue (FY2024) came from customers headquartered in China, and multiple FY2025 reports continue to cite this reliance, implying a similar exposure level in FY2025. In other words, around 45–46% of Qualcomm’s FY2025 revenue is effectively exposed to China demand.

search_results.title: Qualcomm is increasingly exposed to China
search_results.snippet: Light Reading notes Qualcomm’s growing reliance on China: in the prior fiscal year it derived 46% of total revenue from customers with Chinese headquarters (up from 37% a year earlier), underscoring that nearly half of its sales are tied to Chinese market demand going into FY2025.

search_results.title: Qualcomm chip sales to Chinese smartphone makers fuel strong results
search_results.snippet: A Reuters report highlights that Qualcomm derived 46% of revenue in its most recent fiscal year from customers headquartered in China; this continued strength from Chinese Android OEM launches frames Qualcomm’s ongoing mid‑40% revenue exposure to China in FY2025.

search_results.title: Qualcomm revenue worldwide by region 2024 | Statista
search_results.snippet: Statista’s breakdown shows that in FY2024 Qualcomm generated over $17 billion from China & Hong Kong out of ~$35.9 billion total revenue (about 47%), corroborating that around half of the company’s revenue is tied to China—an indicative proxy for FY2025 exposure.

What is Qualcomm's FY2025 QCT gross marg.query: What is Qualcomm's FY2025 QCT gross margin target and primary mix drivers?
What is Qualcomm's FY2025 QCT gross marg.answer: Qualcomm is guiding QCT segment margins at roughly 30% for FY2025 (communicated as QCT EBT margin; the company does not disclose QCT gross margin separately). Management points to a favorable mix as the driver: stronger premium-tier Android handset demand (e.g., Snapdragon 8 Elite/Galaxy S25), and rising contributions from Automotive and IoT, which both grew strongly year over year, offsetting headwinds from lower Apple modem-only volumes and normal seasonality.

search_results.title: Qualcomm Announces Third Quarter Fiscal 2025 Results
search_results.snippet: In Q3 FY2025, QCT EBT margin was 30% (EBT $2.67B on $8.99B QCT revenue). Mix drivers were broad-based: Handsets $6.33B (+7% YoY), Automotive $984M (+21% YoY), and IoT $1.68B (+24% YoY), underscoring diversification into Auto/IoT alongside premium-tier handsets—consistent with maintaining ~30% QCT margins this year.

search_results.title: Qualcomm Announces Second Quarter Fiscal 2025 Results
search_results.snippet: Q2 FY2025 QCT EBT margin was 30% (EBT $2.86B on $9.47B QCT revenue). Revenue mix: Handsets $6.93B (+12% YoY), Automotive $959M (+59% YoY), IoT $1.58B (+27% YoY). These mix gains—premium Android handsets plus Auto/IoT growth—support management’s ~30% QCT margin profile through FY2025.

search_results.title: FY2025 1st Quarter Earnings Presentation
search_results.snippet: Management guided Q2 FY2025 QCT EBT margin to 29%–31% and highlighted record QCT revenues driven by premium-tier handsets and sustained Automotive and IoT momentum. This implies an FY2025 QCT margin target around ~30%, with primary mix drivers being stronger premium Android content (e.g., Galaxy S25/Snapdragon 8 Elite) and diversification into Auto/IoT.

What share of Samsung Galaxy S25 units w.query: What share of Samsung Galaxy S25 units will use Snapdragon globally in 2025?
What share of Samsung Galaxy S25 units w.answer: 100%. Samsung and Qualcomm confirmed the entire Galaxy S25 lineup uses the Snapdragon 8 Elite globally, and analyst estimates cited by PhoneArena put Qualcomm’s share at 100% of S25 chipsets in 2025, with no Exynos variants shipping for this generation.

search_results.title: Samsung Galaxy S25 smartphones are powered by a custom Snapdragon 8 Elite SoC
search_results.snippet: Engadget reports that Samsung’s S25 series uses a custom Snapdragon 8 Elite in every model worldwide—from the base S25 to Plus and Ultra—marking a Snapdragon-only global lineup this year rather than any regional Exynos split.

search_results.title: Samsung's use of the Snapdragon 8 Elite AP on all Galaxy S25 units is a financial boon for Qualcomm
search_results.snippet: PhoneArena cites JP Morgan’s Samik Chatterjee saying Qualcomm’s share of the Galaxy S25 series is 100% after Samsung equipped all S25 units with Snapdragon 8 Elite due to Exynos 2500 yield issues, adding an estimated 12M chips and ~$2B revenue.

search_results.title: Snapdragon 8 Elite for Galaxy: Here’s what Qualcomm has to offer for the Samsung Galaxy S25
search_results.snippet: Soyacincau notes the Snapdragon 8 Elite for Galaxy is used across the board globally in the S25 lineup, confirming that all S25 models—up to the Ultra—ship with Qualcomm silicon rather than Exynos this cycle.

What are Qualcomm's debt maturities and.query: What are Qualcomm's debt maturities and refinancing plans for 2026 through 2028?
What are Qualcomm's debt maturities and.answer: Qualcomm’s FY2024 10-K debt note shows no principal due in fiscal 2026, about $2.0 billion maturing in fiscal 2027, and roughly $961 million in fiscal 2028. To position for these maturities, Qualcomm raised $1.5 billion in May 2025 via new investment‑grade notes due 2030/2032/2035; the prospectus states proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes (which typically include refinancing). Its FY25 filings also show active issuance and repayments during the year, indicating ongoing pre‑funding and refinancing activity ahead of 2027–2028 maturities.

search_results.title: Form 10-K (FY2024) – Complete submission (includes debt note and maturity schedule)
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm’s FY2024 annual report XBRL includes the long-term debt note with ‘Future principal payments’: fiscal 2026: $0; fiscal 2027: $2.0B; fiscal 2028: $961M; and $10.6B thereafter—indicating no 2026 maturities and the next significant maturities in 2027–2028.

search_results.title: Prospectus Supplement (May 2025 notes offering) – Use of proceeds and outstanding notes
search_results.snippet: In May 2025, Qualcomm filed a prospectus for $1.5B of new notes (4.500% due 2030; 4.750% due 2032; 5.000% due 2035). The filing states net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes and lists existing series including the 3.25% notes due 2027 and 1.30% notes due 2028—supporting a plan to refinance upcoming maturities.

search_results.title: Davis Polk: Qualcomm $1.5 billion notes offering (May 2025)
search_results.snippet: Davis Polk confirms Qualcomm’s $1.5B investment‑grade notes offering in May 2025 (2030/2032/2035 maturities), evidencing proactive access to capital markets that bolsters refinancing capacity ahead of 2027–2028 debt maturities.

What is Qualcomm's automotive revenue ba.query: What is Qualcomm's automotive revenue backlog conversion schedule by OEM through FY2027?
What is Qualcomm's automotive revenue ba.answer: Qualcomm does not publish a by‑OEM revenue backlog conversion schedule. Public disclosures and partner announcements indicate conversion timing by OEM via start‑of‑production windows: Stellantis programs begin in 2024, BMW’s Neue Klasse launches in 2025 with Qualcomm’s co‑developed ADAS platform, and Volkswagen Group is slated to start using Qualcomm’s automated driving SoCs across brands from 2026. These program ramps underpin conversion through FY2027, but specific revenue by OEM is not broken out publicly.

search_results.title: How BMW Group and Qualcomm built an automated driving platform on AWS
search_results.snippet: AWS details BMW’s next‑gen ADAS platform, co‑developed with Qualcomm on Snapdragon Ride, for the Neue Klasse vehicles set to launch in 2025; this indicates BMW’s Qualcomm‑enabled production ramp begins in 2025, contributing to revenue conversion thereafter.

search_results.title: Stellantis and Qualcomm Collaborate to Power New Vehicle Platforms with Snapdragon Digital Chassis Solutions
search_results.snippet: Stellantis’ official release states a multi‑year collaboration with Qualcomm, with Snapdragon Digital Chassis deployments beginning in 2024 across 14 brands (starting with Maserati), providing a clear OEM start‑of‑production window for conversion.

search_results.title: Volkswagen to Partner With Qualcomm on Automated Driving Technology: Report
search_results.snippet: Citing Handelsblatt, VW will use Qualcomm’s automated driving SoCs across all Group brands starting in 2026 under a long‑term deal, signaling Volkswagen’s OEM‑specific conversion timing beginning mid‑decade and ramping into FY2027.

What specific incentives is Qualcomm off.query: What specific incentives is Qualcomm offering OEMs to adopt Snapdragon X PCs?
What specific incentives is Qualcomm off.answer: Qualcomm is using heavy go-to-market incentives to lower OEM risk and speed Snapdragon X adoption: it doubled channel funding, lifted market development funds by roughly 150%, and stood up a “lucrative” launch incentive program around Copilot+ PCs. The company also provides co-marketing kits and 100+ partner sales tools, expanded its commercial channel team, and is directly funding channel placement to help OEM designs land in retail and commercial routes to market, alongside enablement with Microsoft.

search_results.title: Qualcomm Doubles Snapdragon X Channel Funding As It ‘Aggressively’ Recruits Partners
search_results.snippet: CRN reports Qualcomm doubled channel funding, boosted market development funds by ~150%, and launched a “lucrative incentive program” to back Copilot+ PC rollouts. It also created commercial partner campaign kits and 100+ sales tools to drive Snapdragon X sell-through—explicit financial and marketing incentives meant to accelerate OEM adoption.

search_results.title: Qualcomm: Snapdragon X Partner Program Is 'Hyper Competitive' Against Intel, AMD
search_results.snippet: In an interview, Qualcomm details pulling “financial levers” (doubling partner funding and quadrupling its commercial channel team) and positioning its program as ‘hyper competitive’ versus Intel/AMD—underscoring the use of funding and partner incentives to scale Snapdragon X PCs with OEMs and the channel.

search_results.title: RESEARCH NOTE: Qualcomm Pulled Off the Impossible with the Snapdragon X AI PC Notebook Platform
search_results.snippet: Moor Insights notes Qualcomm ‘funded the channel to get the OEMs assorted’ in consumer and commercial routes, with Microsoft also investing—evidence of Qualcomm’s direct channel placement funding and co-marketing support aimed at de-risking OEM Snapdragon X launches.

How does MediaTek Dimensity 9400 perform.query: How does MediaTek Dimensity 9400 performance compare to Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 benchmarks?
How does MediaTek Dimensity 9400 perform.answer: Across independent tests, Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 (branded Snapdragon 8 Elite) consistently leads in CPU performance, while GPU and gaming results are effectively a draw. Android Authority’s lab benchmarks show the 8 Elite ahead by about 18% in Geekbench single-core and ~37% in multi-core versus Dimensity 9400, but 3DMark GPU scores and real‑game tests put the two neck‑and‑neck, with MediaTek’s chip often running cooler and sustaining performance well. Device tuning and cooling matter: AnTuTu/3DMark totals are close, and in real games (COD Mobile, PUBG, Genshin) frame rates are nearly indistinguishable, with occasional feature/optimization edges on Qualcomm.

search_results.title: I benchmarked the Snapdragon 8 Elite's biggest competitor and it's great for gaming
search_results.snippet: Android Authority directly compared Dimensity 9400 (OPPO Find X8 Pro) to Snapdragon 8 Elite/Gen 4 (ASUS ROG Phone 9 Pro). In Geekbench 6, Snapdragon 8 Elite led by ~18% single-core and ~37% multi-core, while 3DMark Wild Life Extreme/Solar Bay showed the Dimensity 9400’s GPU right alongside the 8 Elite near the top. The MediaTek chip ran cooler (peaking ~38.8°C) with solid sustained performance, making gaming performance effectively comparable despite the CPU gap.

search_results.title: I tried gaming on Snapdragon's biggest rival and came away surprised
search_results.snippet: In real‑world gaming (COD Mobile 120 fps, PUBG HDR 60 fps, Genshin Impact), Dimensity 9400 and Snapdragon 8 Elite delivered virtually identical frame rates; Qualcomm held a slightly tighter lock in some titles, but MediaTek’s chip matched peak 3DMark performance and maintained lower temperatures during stress tests. Bottom line: GPU/gaming performance is effectively a tie, with Dimensity 9400 showing strong thermal behavior.

search_results.title: Snapdragon 8 Elite vs Dimensity 9400 - Most Balanced Comparison
search_results.snippet: C4ETech’s side‑by‑side benchmarks (Geekbench, AnTuTu, 3DMark Wild Life/Solar Bay, stress and battery) found Snapdragon 8 Elite on top in CPU/AI, while Dimensity 9400’s Immortalis‑G925 GPU was comparable or slightly ahead in some GPU tests. Under sustained load, the MediaTek chip ran cooler and used less power, with overall performance very close between the two depending on device tuning and thermals.

What is the status of EU antitrust revie.query: What is the status of EU antitrust reviews affecting Qualcomm's licensing practices in 2025?
What is the status of EU antitrust revie.answer: As of 2025, there is no active EU antitrust probe specifically targeting Qualcomm’s patent licensing practices. The European Commission’s FRAND/3G licensing investigation was dropped in 2009 after complainants withdrew, and subsequent EU actions have focused on chipset sales conduct (exclusivity and predatory pricing) rather than licensing. In September 2024, the EU General Court largely upheld the Commission’s 2019 predatory pricing decision—again addressing chip pricing, not licensing terms.

search_results.title: Abuse of a dominant position: the General Court largely upholds the fine imposed on Qualcomm
search_results.snippet: In September 2024, the EU General Court largely upheld the Commission’s 2019 decision fining Qualcomm for predatory pricing of UMTS (3G) baseband chipsets, slightly reducing the amount. The case concerns below-cost pricing in chip sales to Huawei and ZTE, indicating ongoing EU antitrust enforcement around pricing conduct rather than Qualcomm’s patent licensing.

search_results.title: Commission drops Qualcomm case over 3G standards

How do Qualcomm's Snapdragon X PCs bench.query: How do Qualcomm's Snapdragon X PCs benchmark against Apple's M3 and AMD Ryzen AI?
How do Qualcomm's Snapdragon X PCs bench.answer: Across independent and vendor-cited tests, Snapdragon X Elite laptops typically beat Apple’s base M3 in multi-core CPU benchmarks but trail in single-core; M3 Pro/Max remain ahead overall, and Apple’s iGPU is stronger for graphics. Versus AMD’s Ryzen AI 300 (HX 370/365), results are mixed: Snapdragon X often edges in multi-core CPU (and Cinebench 2024) with excellent efficiency and battery life, while AMD’s Zen 5 parts match or lead in single-core in some tests and deliver far superior integrated GPU performance and broader x86 gaming/app compatibility. AMD’s NPU is rated up to 50–55 TOPS vs Qualcomm’s 45 TOPS, but Snapdragon X Copilot+ PCs stand out for unplugged performance and endurance.

search_results.title: Snapdragon X Elite vs Intel Core Ultra and Apple M3: Efficiency and performance
search_results.snippet: Notebookcheck reports Snapdragon X Elite outpaces Apple’s base M3 in Geekbench 6 multi-core (≈13,881 vs 11,981; ~16% lead) but loses in single-core (M3 ≈3,119 vs 2,786; ~12% lead). It trails M3 Pro in both single- and multi-core and is well behind M3 Max (~40% gap), though X Elite (23W) can edge the 11‑core M3 Pro in Cinebench 2024 multi-thread. Efficiency is a strong suit at lower power; scaling to 80W yields modest gains and weaker efficiency.

search_results.title: AMD Ryzen AI 300 vs Qualcomm Snapdragon X chips
search_results.snippet: Testing across multiple Snapdragon X Elite laptops versus a Ryzen AI 9 HX 370 shows Snapdragon X often faster in most CPU tests (especially Cinebench 2024 and Geekbench multi-core), with single-core broadly similar; Cinebench R23 favors AMD. Ryzen’s Radeon 890M iGPU and gaming performance are stronger, while Snapdragon generally delivers snappier feel and better battery life. AMD’s NPU reaches up to 50–55 TOPS vs Qualcomm’s 45 TOPS.

search_results.title: [Comparison] AMD Ryzen AI 9 HX 370 vs Snapdragon X Elite – CPU and GPU results
search_results.snippet: LaptopMedia finds Snapdragon X Elite slightly ahead in Cinebench 2024 multi-core (~4% lead) and about 9% ahead in Geekbench 6 multi-core, while Ryzen AI 370 is ~14% stronger in Geekbench single-core. For graphics, AMD’s Radeon 890M crushes X Elite’s Adreno iGPU—about 88% higher in 3DMark Time Spy and modestly ahead in Wildlife Extreme—highlighting AMD’s advantage for integrated GPU and gaming workloads.

What is Qualcomm's reliance on ASE, Amko.query: What is Qualcomm's reliance on ASE, Amkor, and SPIL for advanced packaging in 2025?
What is Qualcomm's reliance on ASE, Amko.answer: In 2025, Qualcomm remains heavily dependent on leading OSATs—ASE (including SPIL) and Amkor—for advanced packaging. Reporting shows Qualcomm has deeply integrated with SPIL in Taiwan (including on-site Qualcomm engineers and equipment), while premium SoC packaging is frequently handled by Amkor. Industry data for 2025 also indicates ASE/SPIL and Amkor are ramping advanced packaging capacity, underscoring Qualcomm’s ongoing reliance on these partners.

search_results.title: Taiwan’s compromise with Qualcomm is a lesson for South Korea

While premium chip packaging orders go to Amkor in Korea, Qualcomm’s close ties with Taiwanese packaging partners (SPIL/ASE) have grown, reflecting strong reliance on both SPIL/ASE and Amkor.

search_results.title: Qualcomm Supply Chain Audit
search_results.snippet: This supply chain audit notes that Qualcomm, as a fabless company, relies on external packaging and test providers primarily in East Asia—specifically ASE and Amkor (and also TSMC’s packaging)—for advanced packaging. It highlights risks from concentrating packaging/testing with a few partners, reinforcing Qualcomm’s dependence on ASE/Amkor in 2025.

What is Qualcomm's weighted average inte.query: What is Qualcomm's weighted average interest rate and hedging strategy on outstanding debt?
What is Qualcomm's weighted average inte.answer: Qualcomm most recently disclosed a weighted‑average interest rate on debt outstanding of about 6.2% (FY2024 Q3), up from roughly 4.6%–4.7% earlier in FY2024. The company’s outstanding borrowings are primarily unsecured fixed‑rate notes, and it manages interest‑rate risk mainly with interest‑rate swaps—designating some as fair‑value hedges to convert portions of fixed‑rate notes to floating and using forward‑starting swaps to lock benchmark rates ahead of new issuances; gains/losses from those hedges are recognized and amortized through interest expense over the related debt.

search_results.title: QUALCOMM Incorporated – FY2024 Form 10-K
search_results.snippet: The 10‑K describes Qualcomm’s borrowings as primarily unsecured fixed‑rate notes and notes that effective interest rates on the notes include coupon, amortization of discounts/issuance costs and, where applicable, hedging adjustments. The filing discusses use of derivatives (interest-rate swaps) to manage market risk within its debt and market‑risk sections.

search_results.title: Debt, Weighted Average Interest Rate (Qualcomm)
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm’s reported weighted‑average interest rate on debt outstanding increased from 4.6% (FY2024 Q1) to 4.7% (FY2024 Q2) and to 6.2% (FY2024 Q3), as reflected in its 10‑Q filings—providing the latest company‑reported borrowing rate across outstanding debt.

search_results.title: QUALCOMM Incorporated – FY2022 Form 10-K
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm details its interest‑rate hedging: at September 25, 2022 it had interest‑rate swaps (about $2.1B notional) designated as fair‑value hedges to convert portions of fixed‑rate notes to floating, and it previously used forward‑starting swaps to lock benchmark rates ahead of a 2022 note issuance; terminated swaps’ gains were reclassified from AOCI and amortized over the life of the related debt.

What is Qualcomm's share of Android flag.query: What is Qualcomm's share of Android flagship modem attach versus internal OEM modems?
What is Qualcomm's share of Android flag.answer: Qualcomm holds the clear majority of modem/SoC attach in Android flagships. Counterpoint shows Qualcomm’s share in the >$500 Android tier reached 71% in Q1 2022 and it powered 75% of Samsung’s Galaxy S22 shipments, displacing Samsung’s in‑house Exynos. Qualcomm and Samsung then signed a multiyear deal, and for the Galaxy S24 cycle Qualcomm’s CEO said Snapdragon would have a ‘majority share,’ with Exynos used only in some regional S24/S24+ models. In short, Qualcomm accounts for most Android flagship modem attach, while internal OEM modems (e.g., Exynos) make up the minority.

This indicates Qualcomm’s modem/SoC attach in Android flagships far exceeds internal OEM modems.

search_results.snippet: On the Q3 FY22 call, CEO Cristiano Amon said Qualcomm’s share at Samsung improved from about 40% versus its in‑house solution to roughly 75% with Galaxy S22, and announced a multiyear agreement to power Galaxy flagships globally through 2030—evidence that Snapdragon modems have the majority attach versus Samsung’s internal Exynos in recent flagships.

What is the current status of ITC invest.query: What is the current status of ITC investigations impacting Qualcomm's handset importation in 2025?
What is the current status of ITC invest.answer: In 2025, Qualcomm is a named respondent in two active USITC Section 337 investigations that could affect smartphone (handset) imports. Investigation No. 337-TA-1443 (Longitude/Marlin) targets foreign-fabricated semiconductors and devices including smartphones; the Commission set an 18-month target completion date of September 29, 2026, indicating the case remains pending through 2025. Investigation No. 337-TA-1450 (Onesta IP) covers integrated circuits and devices such as smartphones and lists Qualcomm among respondents; it was instituted on May 20, 2025 and is proceeding before an ALJ, with the target date to be set per ITC procedure. No exclusion orders have been issued yet in these matters.

search_results.title: Certain Foreign-Fabricated Semiconductor Devices, Products Containing the Same, and Components Thereof — Notice of Commission Determination Not To Review an Initial Determination Setting the Target Date
search_results.snippet: The Commission confirms the ALJ set an 18‑month target date of September 29, 2026 for Inv. No. 337‑TA‑1443 (Longitude Licensing/Marlin v. TSMC, Apple, Broadcom, Lenovo, Motorola, OnePlus, and Qualcomm), with the final initial determination due by May 29, 2026, showing the case remains active through 2025.

search_results.title: Certain Integrated Circuits, Electronic Devices Containing the Same, and Components Thereof — Notice of Institution of Investigation
search_results.snippet: Instituted May 20, 2025, Inv. No. 337‑TA‑1450 names Qualcomm, NVIDIA, OnePlus, and Nothing as respondents. Accused articles include integrated circuits and devices such as smartphones, tablets, smartwatches, and computers; the case proceeds before an ALJ and will have a target date set per ITC rules.

search_results.title: Certain Foreign-Fabricated Semiconductor Devices, Products Containing the Same, and Components Thereof — Notice of Institution of Investigation
search_results.snippet: Inv. No. 337‑TA‑1443 was instituted March 21, 2025 against multiple respondents including Qualcomm. The scope covers non‑x86 semiconductors made on TSMC’s 7nm and smaller nodes and systems containing them—explicitly including smartphones, tablets, PCs, smartwatches, and network units—seeking exclusion and cease‑and‑desist orders.

What are Qualcomm's 2025 wafer pricing t.query: What are Qualcomm's 2025 wafer pricing trends at TSMC N3 for Snapdragon 8 Gen 4?
What are Qualcomm's 2025 wafer pricing t.answer: The trend is upward. Morgan Stanley expects TSMC to lift leading-edge wafer prices in 2025, with 3nm (N3) wafer ASPs rising about 4% from a baseline around $20,000 per wafer—implying modest but real cost pressure on N3/N3E supply. For Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 (built on TSMC N3E), reports indicate per-chip prices to OEMs are up roughly 25–30% versus Gen 3 due to the more expensive N3E process, and Qualcomm has publicly signaled it expects higher costs—suggesting 2025 devices using 8 Gen 4 will reflect these increases.

search_results.snippet: Morgan Stanley projects TSMC will raise wafer prices in 2025, with 3nm wafer ASPs up about 4% and N3 wafers estimated around $20,000+ per wafer. While AI/HPC customers may see up to ~10% hikes, smartphone clients are also expected to accept modest increases—signaling a generally higher 2025 price environment for N3/N3E that would affect Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 supply.

search_results.title: Report: Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 is 30% more expensive, cheaper Windows chips coming in 2025
search_results.snippet: Ming-Chi Kuo says Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 will cost OEMs about $190–$200 per unit (25–30% higher vs Gen 3), primarily because it uses TSMC’s newer and more expensive N3E 3nm process. The report implies Android flagships in 2025 could get pricier as OEMs face higher SoC costs driven by N3E wafer economics.

search_results.snippet: Qualcomm told Android Authority it expects Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 to see a cost increase, and a well-known leaker adds the jump will be “significant.” While figures aren’t given here, the driver is the move to TSMC’s cutting-edge N3E (3nm), suggesting higher foundry and wafer costs will push 2025 flagship phone pricing upward.

What is Qualcomm's roadmap for integrate.query: What is Qualcomm's roadmap for integrated AI vision ISPs in next mobile platforms?
What is Qualcomm's roadmap for integrate.answer: Qualcomm’s roadmap evolves from the Spectra “Cognitive ISP” in Snapdragon 8 Gen 3—triple 18‑bit ISPs with real‑time semantic segmentation—to a rebuilt “AI ISP” in the next flagship Snapdragon 8 Elite (Gen 4). The 8 Elite AI ISP is tightly integrated with the Hexagon NPU via an overhauled Hexagon Direct Link, moves more processing into RAW, boosts throughput by ~35%, and enables features like Limitless Segmentation (>250 layers), real‑time 4K60 AI enhancements, video object eraser, and improved AI-based 3A. This signals a continued push to fuse AI directly into the imaging pipeline across upcoming Snapdragon mobile platforms.

What is Qualcomm's plan to support LLM f.query: What is Qualcomm's plan to support LLM fine-tuning on-device within Snapdragon platforms?
What is Qualcomm's plan to support LLM f.answer: Qualcomm plans to enable on-device LLM fine-tuning through parameter‑efficient methods like LoRA, where small adapters are trained instead of the full model and then run on Snapdragon devices. Using the Qualcomm AI Stack (e.g., AIMET) and AI Hub, Qualcomm compiles and quantizes the base model and LoRA adapters for CPU/GPU/NPU, enabling fast adapter swapping and personalized on-device inference at scale—an approach they have already demonstrated on Snapdragon smartphones and say extends to LLMs for tailored assistants.

search_results.title: What's next in on-device generative AI
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm outlines LoRA as the path to customization and personalization on devices: LoRA reduces trainable parameters (e.g., ~2% of the model), enables personalized on‑device inference at scale, and supports multiple adapters that can be swapped or used in parallel—framing how fine‑tuned adapters run efficiently on Snapdragon hardware.

search_results.title: Qualcomm Continues to Bring the Generative AI Revolution to Devices and Empowers Developers with Qualcomm AI Hub
search_results.snippet: At MWC 2024, Qualcomm showcased LoRA running on an Android smartphone and stated that LoRA is broadly applicable to customized AI models, including large language models, to create tailored personal assistants. The AI Hub provides pre‑optimized models and tooling for on-device deployment across Snapdragon platforms.

search_results.title: Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) for Large Vision Model on a Mobile Device
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm’s NeurIPS demo details their PEFT approach on Snapdragon phones: statically compile and quantize the base model and LoRA adapters once, then switch adapters via fast parameter updates to a small fraction of model parameters. This minimizes memory and enables rapid, on-device customization—an approach transferable to LLM adapters.

What regulatory developments in China co.query: What regulatory developments in China could impact Qualcomm's licensing collections in 2025?
What regulatory developments in China co.answer: China’s State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) issued Anti-Monopoly Guidelines for Standard Essential Patents (SEPs) in November 2024 that intensify oversight of licensing practices. The guidelines emphasize FRAND commitments, ‘good-faith’ negotiations, and ex-ante/in-process supervision, and list conducts like unfairly high royalties, refusal to license, tying, discriminatory terms, and misuse of injunctions as potential abuses—factors that could pressure royalty rates and licensing structures in China in 2025. These build on SAMR’s 2023 Provisions on Prohibiting the Abuse of IP Rights, which empower enforcement against excessive pricing, refusal to deal, discriminatory treatment, and patent pool abuses, and could shape Qualcomm’s QTL collections and negotiations with Chinese OEMs and the supply chain.

They identify potential abuses—unfairly high royalties, refusal to license without justification, tying/bundling, discriminatory treatment, and misuse of injunctions—providing a framework for antitrust scrutiny of SEP licensing in China that could influence royalty setting and collections in 2025.

search_results.title: 禁止滥用知识产权排除、限制竞争行为规定（SAMR令第79号）
search_results.snippet: Effective Aug 1, 2023, SAMR’s Provisions target IP-related antitrust abuses, including excessive pricing in licensing, unjustified refusal to license, tying and unreasonable conditions, differential treatment, and patent pool restrictions, with penalties up to 10% of prior-year sales. The rules also require merger notifications for IP-heavy deals. Together with the 2024 SEP Guidelines, they provide enforcement tools that could affect SEP royalty negotiations and collections in 2025.

What are Qualcomm's 2025 cost-per-wafer.query: What are Qualcomm's 2025 cost-per-wafer trends at N4P and N3 nodes?
What are Qualcomm's 2025 cost-per-wafer.answer: For Qualcomm in 2025, TSMC’s 4nm-class (N4/N4P) wafer pricing is trending up toward about $20,000 per wafer (from roughly $18,000), reflecting ~10% increases. At 3nm (N3 family), wafers are already $20,000+ and Morgan Stanley projected ~4% ASP uplift in 2025; by late 2025, N3P wafer quotes were reportedly ~20% higher than N3E, with Qualcomm’s N3P flagship costs up around 16%. Net-net, 3nm cost-per-wafer is trending above 4nm for Qualcomm in 2025.

search_results.title: [News] TSMC Reportedly Raising N3P Prices 20% Ahead of 2nm Era, Pressuring Qualcomm and MediaTek
search_results.snippet: TrendForce cites China Times/Wccftech that as mobile chips move toward 2nm, TSMC raised 3nm ‘N3P’ wafer prices by about 20% versus N3E; Qualcomm and MediaTek’s late‑2025 N3P flagships reportedly saw 16–24% higher costs. This evidences higher 3nm wafer pricing for Qualcomm in 2025 relative to earlier 3nm and 4nm nodes.

search_results.title: TSMC 2025 Wafer Prices Up 10%, CoWoS Soars 20%
search_results.snippet: Morgan Stanley expects TSMC to lift 2025 wafer prices: 4nm wafers rising from roughly $18,000 to about $20,000 each (~10%), and 3nm wafer ASPs up around 4% with N3 wafers already at or above $20,000. Smartphone clients are accepting modest hikes, implying Qualcomm faces higher N4P and N3 cost‑per‑wafer in 2025.

What initiatives expand Qualcomm's AI so.query: What initiatives expand Qualcomm's AI software ecosystem beyond AI Stack in 2025?
What initiatives expand Qualcomm's AI so.answer: In 2025, Qualcomm broadened its AI software ecosystem beyond the Qualcomm AI Stack by launching the Qualcomm AI Inference Suite and the Qualcomm AI On‑Prem Appliance Solution to operationalize generative AI and computer vision across on‑prem and cloud. It also deepened ecosystem integrations by optimizing IBM Granite models in the Qualcomm AI Hub and incorporating watsonx.governance into the Inference Suite, while securing Red Hat OpenShift certification for its Cloud AI accelerators—expanding deployment, governance, and enterprise readiness.

search_results.title: Qualcomm Launches On-prem AI Appliance Solution and Inference Suite to Step-up AI Inference Privacy, Flexibility and Cost Savings Across Enterprise and Industrial Verticals

The suite adds APIs (OpenAI-compatible), agents, and tools with Kubernetes/container support, while the on‑prem appliance shifts inference from cloud to local to cut TCO; early collaborators include Honeywell, Aetina, and IBM.

search_results.title: Qualcomm and IBM Scale Enterprise-grade Generative AI from Edge to Cloud
search_results.snippet: Ahead of MWC 2025, Qualcomm and IBM expanded collaboration to integrate IBM watsonx.governance into the Qualcomm AI Inference Suite and make IBM Granite 3.1 models available via the Qualcomm AI Hub. Qualcomm’s Cloud AI accelerators also gained Red Hat OpenShift certification, bringing governed model deployment and hybrid edge‑to‑cloud options to Qualcomm’s ecosystem.

search_results.title: AI Inference Suite
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm’s AI Inference Suite (for cloud and on‑prem) enables one‑click deployment of AI models and applications, with ready‑to‑use gen‑AI agents, OpenAI‑compatible APIs, and support for thousands of models. Running on Qualcomm Cloud AI accelerators, it emphasizes high availability and strict data privacy—giving enterprises a turnkey path to operationalize AI beyond device‑level tooling.

What changes occurred in Qualcomm's exec.query: What changes occurred in Qualcomm's executive leadership team during 2025?
What changes occurred in Qualcomm's exec.answer: In 2025, Qualcomm’s executive leadership saw a key technology transition and a finance leadership reshuffle. What cybersecurity incidents have impact.query: What cybersecurity incidents have impacted Qualcomm operations or data in 2024-2025?
What cybersecurity incidents have impact.answer: Public reporting in 2024–2025 centers on in-the-wild exploitation of Qualcomm chipset zero-days, rather than a disclosed breach of Qualcomm’s own corporate systems. In Oct 2024, Qualcomm confirmed CVE-2024-43047 in its DSP FastRPC driver was under limited, targeted exploitation and shipped fixes to OEMs; in Jun 2025 it patched three Adreno GPU zero-days also flagged as being exploited in targeted campaigns. These incidents affected downstream devices and required patches and coordination with device makers; no material Qualcomm corporate data/operations breach was publicly reported in this period.

Patches were provided to OEMs in May; device makers must deliver updates to users, and Google said Pixels were unaffected.

The flaw impacts dozens of chipsets; patches were created and sent to OEMs.

search_results.title: Qualcomm patches high-severity zero-day exploited in attacks
search_results.snippet: On Oct. 7, 2024, Qualcomm patched CVE-2024-43047, a use-after-free in the DSP service leading to memory corruption, which Google TAG and Amnesty tagged as exploited in the wild. Qualcomm urged OEMs to deploy fixes and advised users to apply device-maker updates.

What export licensing requirements restr.query: What export licensing requirements restrict Qualcomm shipments to Chinese automotive customers in 2025?
What export licensing requirements restr.answer: In 2025, U.S. BIS rules expanded “advanced computing” export controls so that AI‑capable chips classified under ECCNs 3A090/4A090 and items containing them require a BIS license to ship to China (including Hong Kong and Macau), with applications generally reviewed under a presumption of denial. BIS also tightened due‑diligence and license‑exception pathways for foundries/packagers and used “is informed” letters to impose immediate license requirements on specific AI chips. Practically, Qualcomm must secure BIS authorization before shipping covered automotive SoCs to Chinese carmakers unless a narrow exception applies.

search_results.title: Commerce Strengthens Restrictions on Advanced Computing Semiconductors to Enhance Foundry Due Diligence and Prevent Diversion to PRC
search_results.snippet: On Jan 15, 2025 BIS broadened export license requirements for certain advanced chips and limited license exceptions to approved designers/OSATs, while adding PRC entities to the Entity List. The update reinforces controls aimed at preventing diversion to China; shipments of covered advanced chips to PRC customers require a BIS license, affecting AI‑capable SoCs used in sectors like automotive if they meet performance thresholds.

search_results.title: US Commerce Dept. Rule Expands Licensing Requirements
search_results.snippet: The Jan 13, 2025 interim final rule places worldwide controls on advanced computing ICs (ECCNs 3A090/4A090). Shipments to entities in China (incl. Hong Kong and Macau) generally require a BIS license and are reviewed with a presumption of denial. New License Exception AIA applies only to allied “Supplement 5” countries, so China‑bound AI chips typically need licenses—implicating AI‑capable automotive SoCs.

search_results.title: Trade Compliance Flash: Key Takeaways from New BIS Restrictions on AI Chips to China
search_results.snippet: In April 2025, BIS imposed new export license requirements via “is informed” letters on certain AI chips to China (including Hong Kong and Macau), citing diversion risks to PRC supercomputers. This demonstrates BIS’s tighter, immediate licensing of AI chips to China—indicating China‑bound shipments of covered AI chips (including those embedded in automotive systems) need BIS licenses.

What outcomes resulted from Qualcomm's 2.query: What outcomes resulted from Qualcomm's 2025 interactions with India's CCI on licensing?
What outcomes resulted from Qualcomm's 2.answer: There were no reported, Qualcomm-specific outcomes from the CCI in 2025 regarding its licensing practices. Instead, a key 2025 development was India’s Supreme Court affirming that the CCI lacks jurisdiction over patent licensing disputes (including SEP/FRAND issues), leaving such matters to the Patents Act and the Controller of Patents. As a result, there was no new CCI enforcement or order altering Qualcomm’s licensing approach in India in 2025.

search_results.title: Indian competition law roundup: September 2025
search_results.snippet: On 2 Sept 2025, the Supreme Court held that the Competition Commission of India lacks jurisdiction to investigate patentees’ licensing practices, affirming Delhi High Court orders that quashed probes into Ericsson and Monsanto. The Court emphasized that remedies for patent-licensing conduct lie under the Patents Act and with the Controller of Patents, not the CCI.

search_results.title: SC: Patents Act Prevails Over Competition Act in Licensing
search_results.snippet: In Sept 2025, India’s Supreme Court dismissed CCI appeals and endorsed the view that patent licensing disputes fall under the Patents Act. It confirmed that CCI investigations into Ericsson and Monsanto could not continue, noting settlements and clarifying that patent-licensing issues are for the Controller of Patents and civil courts.

search_results.title: Patent assertions are off limits for antitrust watchdog: Supreme Court of India throws out appeal of Ericsson’s Delhi HC win
search_results.snippet: On 2 Sept 2025, the Supreme Court dismissed CCI’s appeal, effectively foreclosing CCI investigations into standard-essential patent licensing assertions. The decision ended a long-running Ericsson matter and signals that CCI cannot pursue patent-licensing conduct that is governed by the Patents Act.

What portion of Qualcomm's debt carries.query: What portion of Qualcomm's debt carries fixed rates versus floating as of 2025?
What portion of Qualcomm's debt carries.answer: As of mid-2025, Qualcomm’s borrowings are almost entirely fixed-rate senior notes. At June 29, 2025, short‑term debt was zero and outstanding fixed‑rate notes were about $13.9B, so instrumentally the mix was ~100% fixed and ~0% floating. However, Qualcomm swapped the full $1.5B of its May 2025 notes from fixed to floating, making roughly $1.5B (~10%) effectively floating and the remainder (~90%) effectively fixed.

At June 29, 2025, outstanding fixed‑rate notes had an aggregate fair value of ~$13.9B and short‑term debt was $0. The company also entered interest rate swaps (notional $1.5B) that convert all payments on the May 2025 notes from fixed to floating.

search_results.title: QUALCOMM Incorporated – Form 10-Q for quarter ended March 30, 2025

What is Qualcomm's CEO compensation stru.query: What is Qualcomm's CEO compensation structure for 2025 and performance metrics emphasis?
What is Qualcomm's CEO compensation stru.answer: Qualcomm’s 2025 proxy shows CEO pay is predominantly performance-based. The structure includes a fixed base salary ($1.35m), an annual cash incentive (target 200% of salary) funded by one‑year Adjusted Revenues and Adjusted Operating Income with a human‑capital modifier, and long‑term equity awards primarily in PSUs tied to three‑year relative TSR (vs. Nasdaq‑100) and Adjusted EPS, plus time‑vested RSUs. Payouts are capped at 2x, RTSR PSUs cannot exceed target if absolute TSR is negative, and the CEO’s target mix is ~94% at risk (about 50% PSUs, 33% RSUs, 11% cash, 6% salary).

search_results.title: Qualcomm Inc — 2025 Proxy Statement (DEF 14A) [PDF]
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm’s 2025 Proxy details the CEO program: base salary plus an Annual Cash Incentive Plan funded by one‑year Adjusted Revenues and Adjusted Operating Income, modified for human capital advancements; long‑term equity is primarily PSUs measured over three years on relative TSR and Adjusted EPS, with RSUs vesting over three years. Payouts are capped at 2x (with an additional cap if absolute TSR is negative), and the CEO’s target mix is ~94% at risk (~50% PSUs, 33% RSUs, 11% cash, 6% salary).

search_results.title: QUALCOMM INC/DE — 2025 Proxy Statement (DEF 14A) — SEC.gov
search_results.snippet: The SEC‑filed 2025 Proxy shows the CEO’s annual bonus (ACIP) target is 200% of salary (Amon’s $1.35m salary implies a $2.7m target) with FY2024 payout at 139% ($3.753m). It outlines PSU performance curves (RTSR: threshold 25th percentile, target 55th, max 90th; EPS PSUs: 0.33x/1x/2x) and confirms the metrics mix—ACIP uses one‑year Adjusted Revenues and Adjusted Operating Income with a human‑capital modifier; PSUs use three‑year RTSR and Adjusted EPS.

search_results.title: Qualcomm big cheese Cristiano Amon's pay award jumps 10%
search_results.snippet: News report citing Qualcomm’s 2025 Proxy: Amon’s FY2024 total compensation was $25.91m, composed of $1.35m salary, $20m stock awards, $3.75m non‑equity incentive, and ~$0.83m other pay—illustrating a structure that relies heavily on equity and performance‑based bonus elements disclosed in the 2025 proxy.

What are Qualcomm's 2025 foundry diversi.query: What are Qualcomm's 2025 foundry diversity plans to mitigate single-supplier risk?
What are Qualcomm's 2025 foundry diversi.answer: Qualcomm is preparing to mitigate single‑supplier risk in 2025 by exploring dual-sourcing of its next flagship mobile SoC. Executives signaled they may split Snapdragon 8 Gen 5 production between TSMC and Samsung, and the company requested 2nm prototype runs from both foundries to evaluate yields, costs, and capacity. Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 remains TSMC-only, with diversification potentially starting from Gen 5 in 2025.

search_results.title: Qualcomm could split Snapdragon 8 Gen 5 production between Samsung and TSMC
search_results.snippet: At a June 4, 2024 media briefing in Taiwan, CEO Cristiano Amon said Qualcomm is considering dual-sourcing Snapdragon 8 Gen 5 across TSMC and Samsung to reduce reliance on a single manufacturer and manage costs; Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 remains TSMC-only, with diversification likely starting from Gen 5 (shipping in 2025).

search_results.title: Qualcomm asks Samsung Foundry and TSMC to each build 2nm Snapdragon 8 prototypes
search_results.snippet: ETNews reports Qualcomm requested 2nm prototype chips from both Samsung Foundry and TSMC for the next-gen Snapdragon 8, with mass production expected in 2025; Qualcomm will decide to single-source or dual-source Gen 5 based on sample results, a move aimed at diversifying beyond a single foundry.

search_results.title: Qualcomm confirms it will dual-source chips from Samsung Foundry and TSMC
search_results.snippet: In an ETNews interview, Qualcomm executives said they must diversify foundry sources due to demand and TSMC capacity limits, staying open to Samsung Foundry for future needs; dual-sourcing could align with Samsung’s 3GAP and TSMC nodes, with Snapdragon 8 Gen 5-era chips expected to reach devices in 2025.

What legal contingencies remain after Qu.query: What legal contingencies remain after Qualcomm's 2025 victory over Arm in Delaware?
What legal contingencies remain after Qu.answer: Two legal contingencies remain. First, Arm has appealed the Delaware judgment to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, which could affirm, reverse, or remand. Second, Qualcomm’s separate counter-suit against Arm in Delaware continues and is slated for trial in March 2026.

search_results.snippet: After the Delaware court dismissed Arm’s final claim and confirmed Qualcomm’s licenses, Arm told The Register it will appeal. The article also notes that Qualcomm’s separate counter-suit against Arm remains active, with a trial expected in March 2026—indicating ongoing exposure despite Qualcomm’s courtroom win.

search_results.title: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF DELAWARE – Memorandum Opinion (Arm Ltd. v. Qualcomm Inc., No. 22-1146)
search_results.snippet: Judge Maryellen Noreika’s 9/30/2025 Memorandum Opinion denied Arm’s post-trial bid for judgment or a new trial and granted in part Nuvia’s motion, upholding the December 2024 verdict: Qualcomm’s CPUs were licensed under its ALA and neither Qualcomm nor Nuvia breached the Nuvia ALA—the final district-court ruling underpinning Qualcomm’s 2025 victory.

What steps is Qualcomm taking to expand.query: What steps is Qualcomm taking to expand Snapdragon AR2 and XR2 enterprise adoption?
What steps is Qualcomm taking to expand.answer: Qualcomm is accelerating enterprise adoption by expanding its Snapdragon Spaces XR Developer Platform (e.g., Dual Render Fusion) so mobile developers can extend 2D apps into 3D AR experiences, and by growing a large enterprise-focused ISV ecosystem. It’s partnering with global operators (e.g., Deutsche Telekom, Telefonica, KDDI, T‑Mobile) to define device requirements and run regional developer programs, and is seeding applications via the Snapdragon Metaverse Fund. On hardware, Qualcomm provides XR2 reference designs and new developer kits (e.g., OPPO MR Glass via EnlightXR), supports enterprise devices like Lenovo ThinkReality VRX and DigiLens ARGO, and has optimized the Snapdragon AR2 platform to be “Spaces Ready” with Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 hosts as part of an end-to-end stack (hardware, perception tech, and software tools).

search_results.snippet: Qualcomm is scaling enterprise XR by enhancing Snapdragon Spaces (e.g., Dual Render Fusion) so mobile developers can turn 2D apps into world‑scale 3D AR without prior XR expertise, expanding a community of ISVs across collaboration, productivity, and training. It is also growing device support (OPPO MR Glass, DigiLens ARGO, TCL RayNeo) and shipping developer kits via EnlightXR, while Qualcomm Ventures’ Metaverse Fund investments (e.g., Survios, EnlightXR, Tangle) help seed applications and ecosystem growth.

search_results.title: Qualcomm’s Mobile-Focused Open Approach To The AR Ecosystem Of The Future
search_results.snippet: At AWE, Qualcomm detailed steps to scale enterprise XR: operator partnerships (China Mobile, Deutsche Telekom, KDDI, NTT QONOQ, T‑Mobile, Telefonica, Vodafone, Claro) to define device requirements and run developer programs; integration with Niantic Lightship VPS; and broader hardware support (DigiLens ARGO as a standalone enterprise AR headset, Lenovo ThinkReality A3/VRX). Dual Render Fusion helps reuse smartphone compute, lowering friction and accelerating AR2/XR2 deployment for business use cases.

search_results.title: Qualcomm Launches Snapdragon AR2 Designed to Revolutionize AR Glasses
search_results.snippet: Qualcomm positions AR2 for enterprise by pairing a low‑power, distributed multi‑chip design with an end‑to‑end stack—hardware, perception tech, and software—with AR2 and Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 optimized to be “Snapdragon Spaces Ready.” Alongside broad OEM engagement (e.g., Lenovo, OPPO, TCL, Vuzix, Xiaomi), this approach anchors AR2 within the Spaces developer ecosystem so enterprises can build and deploy headworn AR solutions more easily.

What risks threaten Snapdragon X PC adop.query: What risks threaten Snapdragon X PC adoption due to Windows app compatibility in 2025?
What risks threaten Snapdragon X PC adop.answer: Snapdragon X PC adoption in 2025 is threatened by lingering Windows app compatibility gaps. Microsoft’s own guidance says x86/x64 emulation (Prism) can’t handle kernel-mode code, so drivers and deeply integrated apps (anti-cheat, some security/VPN clients, virtualization tools, and peripheral drivers) must be rebuilt for Arm64—leaving breakage and uncertainty. Reporting also shows no official master list of incompatible software; buyers are pushed to community trackers, and OEMs have warned that some antivirus and games won’t run. Even platform features like Android apps (WSA) remain broken on Snapdragon X hardware despite support until March 2025, signaling real-world app gaps that can deter mainstream and enterprise adoption.

search_results.title: How emulation works on Arm
search_results.snippet: Microsoft explains that Windows 11 on Arm uses the Prism emulator for x86/x64 apps but emulation only supports user‑mode code; kernel‑mode components like drivers must be compiled Arm64. That means anti‑cheat, security/VPN clients, virtualization layers, and other driver‑dependent apps won’t work via emulation and require native Arm64 support—highlighting a key risk to app compatibility on Snapdragon X PCs.

search_results.title: Copilot+ PCs software compatibility issues left to you to sort out, with help from crowdsourcers
search_results.snippet: The Register reports that buyers concerned about Snapdragon X app support are directed to community sites (WorksOnWoA, Armrepo) because no official incompatible‑software list exists. Samsung warned that its Snapdragon‑based GalaxyBook Edge 4 can’t run some common software (including antivirus and games), underscoring ongoing uncertainty and user burden to verify compatibility.

search_results.title: Developer forced to fix Android apps on Snapdragon laptops after Microsoft’s refusal to do something
search_results.snippet: TechSpot notes that Windows Subsystem for Android (WSA) is supported until March 5, 2025, yet on new Snapdragon X Elite/Plus PCs it’s preinstalled but nonfunctional; Microsoft said it won’t fix it, and a developer created a workaround. This shows that even headline features can be broken on Snapdragon X hardware, signaling practical app‑compatibility gaps that can hinder adoption.

What debt repayment plans does Qualcomm.query: What debt repayment plans does Qualcomm have for callable notes maturing in 2025-2027?

What is the status of Qualcomm's appeals.query: What is the status of Qualcomm's appeals in any ongoing EU legal matters 2025?
What is the status of Qualcomm's appeals.answer: As of 2025, Qualcomm’s Apple exclusivity case is closed: the European Commission decided in September 2022 not to appeal the General Court’s annulment of the €997m fine. In the separate predatory pricing case, the General Court on 18 September 2024 largely upheld the Commission’s 2019 decision (reducing the fine to about €238.7m); any further appeal is to the Court of Justice, and no final CJEU judgment is publicly available yet.

All S25 models ship with Wi‑Fi 7, and the lineup’s Snapdragon 8 Elite/Qualcomm FastConnect 7900 connectivity means Qualcomm provides the Wi‑Fi 7 socket across Samsung’s 2025 flagships. More broadly, Qualcomm’s FastConnect 7900 is the integrated Wi‑Fi 7/BT/UWB solution expected in 2025 Snapdragon flagships, reducing the need for separate Broadcom combo chips.

What is Qualcomm's exposure to potential.query: What is Qualcomm's exposure to potential U.S. tariffs on electronics imported from China?
What is Qualcomm's exposure to potential.answer: Qualcomm’s direct exposure appears limited: current U.S. tariff regimes have generally exempted smartphones and many semiconductors, and management says it sees no material direct impact from tariffs. The bigger risk is indirect—if the U.S. were to impose tariffs on finished electronics assembled in China (e.g., smartphones), higher device prices could dampen U.S. demand and weigh on Qualcomm’s chip sales; its 10-K also flags elevated sensitivity due to China concentration and evolving U.S.–China trade policies.

What data privacy regulations affect Qua.query: What data privacy regulations affect Qualcomm's Snapdragon Aware services deployments in 2025?
What data privacy regulations affect Qua.answer: In 2025, Snapdragon Aware deployments must navigate: (1) the EU GDPR’s cross‑border transfer regime, using Standard Contractual Clauses with transfer impact assessments and enhanced transparency/data‑subject protections for EEA data; (2) a rapidly expanding patchwork of U.S. state privacy laws (CPRA plus 2025‑effective laws in states like IA, NJ, TN, MN, MD, etc.) requiring notices, consumer rights, DPIAs and recognition of opt‑out signals; and (3) China’s PIPL as updated by CAC’s March 2024 regulations, which set thresholds and exemptions for cross‑border transfers but still require consent and PIAs. These govern location/IoT data collection, processing, and international transfers relevant to Snapdragon Aware.

search_results.title: US State Privacy Legislation Tracker
search_results.snippet: IAPP’s tracker details which comprehensive U.S. state privacy laws are in force in 2025 and when, e.g., Iowa (Jan. 1, 2025), New Jersey (Jan. 15, 2025), Tennessee and Minnesota (mid‑2025), and Maryland (Oct. 1, 2025), and sets out obligations such as privacy notices, data protection assessments, enforcement timelines, cure periods, and recognition of opt‑out signals. Services processing U.S. resident data must align with these state statutes in addition to California’s CPRA.

search_results.title: New Standard Contractual Clauses - Questions and Answers overview
search_results.snippet: The European Commission explains that GDPR‑compliant transfers of personal data outside the EEA rely on updated Standard Contractual Clauses that embed enhanced transparency, data‑subject rights, breach notification, and onward‑transfer controls. Parties must perform transfer impact assessments and address government‑access requests, making SCCs a primary tool Qualcomm would use for cross‑border Snapdragon Aware data flows involving the EU.

search_results.title: China Released New Regulations to Ease Requirements for Outbound Cross-Border Data Transfers
search_results.snippet: China’s CAC March 22, 2024 regulations relax—but do not remove—PIPL cross‑border controls: exemptions for certain scenarios, higher thresholds (e.g., standard contract/certification for transfers of >100k but <1M individuals; security assessment above 1M; sensitive PI triggers), and extended assessment validity. Companies must still obtain consent, conduct PIAs, and monitor volumes, impacting Snapdragon Aware deployments involving China‑origin personal data.

reranked.query: What secured 3nm foundry capacity has Qualcomm booked at TSMC through 2026?

reranked.title: Qualcomm may source 3nm chips from TSMC and Samsung
reranked.snippet: Citing Commercial Times, TechNode reports Qualcomm plans to dual-source Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 on 3nm, partnering with TSMC (N3E) and Samsung as Apple is expected to consume much of TSMC’s early 3nm capacity; Samsung’s improving 3nm yields make it a practical backup to mitigate N3 constraints.
reranked.query: What contingency plans exist if TSMC N3 yields constrain Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 volumes?

reranked.title: Qualcomm confirms it will dual-source chips from Samsung Foundry and TSMC
reranked.snippet: Qualcomm executives told ETNews the company must diversify due to high demand and limited TSMC capacity, confirming it is open to Samsung Foundry and a multi-foundry strategy; dual-sourcing could begin as Samsung’s 3GAP reaches high-volume production, providing a contingency if TSMC 3nm supply is tight.
reranked.query: What contingency plans exist if TSMC N3 yields constrain Snapdragon 8 Gen 4 volumes?

reranked.title: How BMW Group and Qualcomm built an automated driving platform on AWS
reranked.snippet: AWS details BMW’s next‑gen ADAS platform, co‑developed with Qualcomm on Snapdragon Ride, for the Neue Klasse vehicles set to launch in 2025; this indicates BMW’s Qualcomm‑enabled production ramp begins in 2025, contributing to revenue conversion thereafter.
reranked.query: What is Qualcomm's automotive revenue backlog conversion schedule by OEM through FY2027?

reranked.title: Premium Smartphone SoC Revenues Rise 34% YoY in 2024, Account for Half of Total Android Smartphone SoC Revenues
reranked.snippet: Counterpoint says that in 2025 Qualcomm will maintain a dominant position in the premium Android SoC market, driven by its exclusive partnership on Samsung’s Galaxy S25 series and broad design wins across Android OEMs. MediaTek’s premium gains are concentrated in China through vivo/OPPO/Xiaomi, while HiSilicon also resurged domestically—implying Qualcomm’s premium-tier lead outside China and tougher competition inside China.
reranked.query: What is Qualcomm's Android premium-tier share versus MediaTek in 2025 by region?

reranked.title: Qualcomm announces Snapdragon 8 Elite with Oryon CPU cores and confirms Asus, Honor, iQOO, OnePlus, Oppo, realme, Samsung, Vivo and Xiaomi release plans
reranked.snippet: At Snapdragon Summit, Qualcomm unveiled Snapdragon 8 Elite and said Chinese OEMs including Honor, iQOO, OnePlus, Oppo, realme, Vivo and Xiaomi would announce the first devices in the coming weeks, confirming broad 2025 flagship adoption in China.
reranked.query: What are Qualcomm's 2025 design wins for Chinese Android flagships using Snapdragon 8 Gen 4?

reranked.title: The S25 Ultra is more expensive to make than the S24 Ultra, and it's thanks to this part
reranked.snippet: Counterpoint’s BoM analysis finds the Galaxy S25 Ultra costs ~3.4% more to make than the S24 Ultra, driven largely by an estimated 21% increase in processor cost from moving to Snapdragon 8 Elite for Galaxy; camera, RF and casing costs fell—underscoring higher Qualcomm processor content per device in 2025.
reranked.query: What is Qualcomm's 2025 content increase per device in Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra?

reranked.title: Qualcomm Doubles Snapdragon X Channel Funding As It ‘Aggressively’ Recruits Partners
reranked.snippet: CRN reports Qualcomm doubled channel funding, boosted market development funds by ~150%, and launched a “lucrative incentive program” to back Copilot+ PC rollouts. It also created commercial partner campaign kits and 100+ sales tools to drive Snapdragon X sell-through—explicit financial and marketing incentives meant to accelerate OEM adoption.
reranked.query: What specific incentives is Qualcomm offering OEMs to adopt Snapdragon X PCs?

reranked.title: Qualcomm stock downgraded on tempered AI PC outlook, target raised
reranked.snippet: HSBC cut Qualcomm to Hold after reassessing AI PC prospects and now models Snapdragon X Elite/X Plus shipments at lower ASPs, forecasting around $60M of AI CPU revenue in FY2024 and about $420M in FY2025—implying roughly 1% of company sales next year under its base case.
reranked.query: What 2025 revenue contribution is expected from Qualcomm's Snapdragon X Elite PC platforms?

reranked.title: Qualcomm Says Snapdragon Powers 1 In 10 Windows Laptops But There's A Caveat
reranked.snippet: Qualcomm noted early traction for Snapdragon X PCs—over 10% share of greater‑than‑$800 Windows laptops in U.S. retail during December and 80+ designs planned or launched in 2025—context that supports a modest 2025 revenue ramp from Snapdragon X Elite/X Plus platforms.
reranked.query: What 2025 revenue contribution is expected from Qualcomm's Snapdragon X Elite PC platforms?

reranked.title: Q2 2025 Qualcomm Inc Earnings Call (Transcript)
reranked.snippet: On the Q2 FY25 call, management reported QCT Automotive up 59% YoY to $959M on increased content in new vehicle launches with Snapdragon Digital Chassis—implying higher per‑vehicle ASPs. IoT rose 27% YoY with Industrial the largest growth driver as the market shifts from microcontrollers to microprocessors and on‑device AI (a favorable mix shift), and Handsets grew 12% YoY on premium‑tier Android shipments. Together, these mix changes point to higher ASPs across Auto and IoT and a richer handset mix in 2025.
