report:
# Qualcomm (QCOM) — BULLISH; BUY

Next market day call: modestly positive bias. We expect QCOM to trade slightly higher versus semis peers, supported by continued premium-tier smartphone momentum (global Galaxy S25 win), resilient QCT margins, and visible capital return, with China headlines as the principal swing factor [10][2][3][6][7][23][11][12][13].

## Executive Summary
- Rating: BUY (BULLISH). Risk/reward skews favorable on:
  - Durable premium Android share and content tailwinds (global Samsung Galaxy S25, broad China flagship wins) [10][24][25][32][33].
  - QCT margin resilience at ~30% through FY25 despite PC ramp, underpinned by richer handset mix and rising Auto/IoT mix; Q4 margin guide remains within guardrails [2][3][4][1].
  - Non-handset growth accelerating (Auto +35% YoY; IoT +20% YoY FY25 guide), expanding to roughly a quarter of revenue each quarter YTD [1][21][3][2].
  - High-margin QTL remains a profit anchor (EBT margin high-60s to low-70s), with near-term revenue guided for seasonal handset units [4][7].
  - Robust shareholder returns (targeting ~100% of FY25 FCF; accelerating buybacks; rising dividend) [6][7][21][23].
- Offsets: Elevated China exposure (~45–50% of revenue), Huawei-related export/license risks, foundry cost inflation (N4P/N3), and execution risk in AI PCs (2025 revenue small but strategic) [11][12][13][14][26][27][35][34].

## Company Overview
Qualcomm operates two primary segments:
- QCT: Snapdragon platforms across Handsets, Automotive, IoT/edge and Windows-on-Arm PCs.
- QTL: Licensing of cellular SEPs and related IP.
FY25 to date, QCT Handsets anchor revenue while IoT/Auto are expanding share; QTL delivers high-margin royalty streams [21][3][2][7].

## Key Findings by Category

### Revenue and Guidance
- FY25 trajectory: management targets ~12% revenue and ~16% non-GAAP EPS growth vs. FY24; QCT non-Apple revenue growth >15% YoY; within QCT, FY25 IoT ~+20% and Auto ~+35% YoY [1].
- Quarterly mix is broad-based:
  - Q1 FY25: Total revenue $11.67B; QCT Handsets $7.57B, Auto $0.96B, IoT $1.55B (Auto+IoT ~22% of total) [21].
  - Q2 FY25: $10.98B; QCT Handsets $6.93B, Auto $0.96B, IoT $1.58B (Auto+IoT ~23%) [3].
  - Q3 FY25: $10.37B; QCT Handsets $6.33B, Auto $0.98B, IoT $1.68B (Auto+IoT ~26%) [2].
- Near-term guide: Q4 FY25 revenue $10.3–$11.1B; QCT $9.0–$9.6B; QTL $1.25–$1.45B [2].

### Margins and Mix
- QCT EBT margin delivered 30% in Q2 and Q3; Q4 guide 27–29% as seasonality and PC ramp are managed within margin guardrails [3][2][1].
- Management attributes margin stability to premium Android mix, expanding Auto content, and industrial IoT growth; PC ramp modestly dilutive but contained [4].
- QTL profitability remains a ballast: EBT margin guided high-60s to low-70s; QTL revenue guided $1.15–$1.35B with seasonal handset units [7][4].

### Product and Competitive Positioning
- Premium Android leadership:
  - Samsung Galaxy S25 globally uses Snapdragon 8 Elite across all models, supporting share and content uplift in 2025 [10].
  - Counterpoint expects Qualcomm to maintain premium-tier dominance in 2025, particularly outside China; MediaTek’s premium gains remain more China-centric [25][24].
  - China OEMs (Honor, iQOO, OnePlus, Oppo, realme, Vivo, Xiaomi) slated to ship Snapdragon 8 Elite flagships, reinforcing breadth of wins [32].
  - BoM work indicates higher processor content in Galaxy S25 Ultra (processor cost +21% YoY), a direct ASP/content tailwind for Qualcomm [33].
- Automotive acceleration:
  - Near-term milestones: L2+ commercialization in 2025; 2H25 launch of BMW’s AD/ADAS stack; 2026 SOP for Snapdragon Flex (unified cockpit+ADAS), supporting conversion of a sizable design pipeline [18][31].
- PCs and on-device AI:
  - Qualcomm is catalyzing Windows-on-Arm via Snapdragon X Elite/X Plus; >10% share of $800+ U.S. Windows retail laptops early in ramp; 80+ designs planned/launched in 2025, >100 by 2026 [20][36].
  - Channel/partner incentives have been increased materially to accelerate adoption and sell-through [34].
  - FY25 AI PC revenue modeled modestly by some on the Street (~$420M), but strategic positioning is long-term with an FY29 PC revenue ambition embedded in IoT (~$4B) [35][19].

### Supply Chain, Foundry and Costs
- Capacity security:
  - TSMC 3nm capacity reported fully booked through 2026; Qualcomm is a named capacity holder [28].
  - Qualcomm has multi-year capacity prepayments ($2.7B at 3/30/25; $2.4B at 6/29/25) to secure supply [22][5].
- Cost environment:
  - 2025 wafer pricing expected to rise: ~10% for 4nm; ~4% for 3nm on average, implying incremental COGS pressure that must be offset by mix and pricing [26][27].
- Contingency:
  - Qualcomm is prepared to dual-source advanced nodes with Samsung Foundry if TSMC N3 yields/capacity constrain volumes [29][30].

### Capital Allocation and Balance Sheet
- Capital return: Qualcomm targets returning ~100% of FY25 FCF via dividends and buybacks; $3.8B returned in Q3 (incl. $2.8B repurchases), $2.7B in Q1; cumulative buybacks since Nov-2024 authorization at ~$5.3B by Q3 [6][7][21][23].
- Dividend: quarterly dividend was increased in FY25 [21].
- Debt and liquidity:
  - Predominantly fixed-rate debt outstanding (~$13.9B fair value at 6/29/25); refinanced $1.4B May-2025 maturity with $1.5B in new fixed notes (2030/2032/2035); no short-term debt outstanding at quarter-end [5].
  - $4B undrawn, multi-currency revolver maturing 2029; standard covenants, minimum 3.0x interest coverage [16].
  - Upcoming maturities include 2027 and 2028 notes; refinancing flexibility affirmed [15].

### Geographic and Customer Concentration
- China concentration remains high (~46–47% of revenue), exposing QCOM to policy, competitive, and demand risks [11][13].
- Huawei risk: U.S. revoked certain export licenses; Qualcomm saw no Huawei QTL revenue in Q2 FY25 due to an expired license; renegotiation/collection and broader China demand remain key watch items [12][14].
- Top customer concentration is elevated (top three customers ~54% YTD through Q3 FY25), reinforcing counterparty risk focus [5].

### Long-Term Strategy and Targets
- Management targets $22B of non-handset revenue by FY29; near-term actions include scaling AI PCs through OEM/retail/commercial channels, new industrial IoT platforms, and converting the auto design pipeline (incl. BMW ADAS) [17][18].

## Investment Thesis

### Bull Case
- Premium-tier smartphone strength, anchored by global Galaxy S25 and broad China flagship wins, yields above-market growth and ASP/content uplift; premium share lead is durable ex-China [10][24][25][32][33].
- Non-handset flywheel is turning: FY25 IoT and Auto growth outpace Handsets, with Auto ramps (BMW stack in 2H25) and industrial IoT mix lifting margins and smoothing cycles [1][18][31][3][2].
- Margin resilience: QCT EBT margins near 30% through FY25, despite PC ramp; QTL high-margin base supports consolidated profitability [3][2][4][7].
- Capital return and balance sheet strength provide downside support and EPS accretion via buybacks; dividend growth affirms cash flow durability [6][7][21][23].
- Supply chain secured via capacity prepayments and dual-sourcing strategy; 3nm capacity bookings reduce risk of allocation shortfalls [22][5][28][29][30].

### Bear Case
- China concentration and Huawei license/export dynamics could pressure both QTL and QCT revenues; competitive resurgence (HiSilicon domestically, MediaTek in China) could limit share/pricing [11][12][13][14][25].
- Foundry cost inflation (N4P/N3) compresses gross margins if not offset by price/mix; PC ramp could dilute near-term QCT margins [26][27][4].
- Customer concentration magnifies negotiating leverage and cyclical volatility; Apple modem supply visibility only through 2026 [5][9][8].

## Key Risks
- China demand/policy: export license revocations, tariff/sanction risk, or competitive shifts in China could disrupt shipments and licensing collections [11][12][14][13].
- Advanced-node supply and cost: N3/N4P price increases and yield bottlenecks; mitigation via mix/pricing and dual-sourcing execution risk [26][27][28][29][30].
- Customer concentration and renewals: top-three exposure (~54%) and time-bound agreements (e.g., Apple modem supply through 2026; Apple license through March 2027) [5][9][8].
- AI PC adoption trajectory: Street expectations vary; 2025 revenue contribution is currently small, and sell-through depends on ecosystem maturity despite increased incentives [35][34][20][36].
- Legal/regulatory outcomes and standards licensing: timing, collection, and rate disputes could affect QTL revenue and margins [4][7][14].

## Next Market Day Setup
- Bias: slight positive. Supportive factors include:
  - Ongoing capital return (buybacks in market), high-margin QTL stability, and resilient QCT margin guardrails [6][7][23][4][2][3][1].
  - Continued positive news flow around Galaxy S25 volumes and Snapdragon content uplift [10][33].
  - Non-handset momentum (Auto/IoT) as a recurring theme in recent results [1][2][3].
- Watch items:
  - Any incremental China/Huawei headlines (policy or competitive) [11][12][14].
  - Foundry pricing/yield chatter and PC sell-through checks [26][27][35][36].

## Conclusion and Outlook
- Recommendation: BUY (BULLISH). We see continued execution in premium Android, a credible non-handset growth bridge (Auto/IoT/PC), strong capital return, and a fortified supply chain offsetting geopolitical and cost headwinds.
- 12-month outlook: Positive skew. We expect FY25 revenue/EPS growth (~12%/~16%) to sustain investor confidence into FY26, with incremental upside from Auto ramps (BMW 2H25) and broader IoT/industrial mix, while AI PC remains a call option that grows in FY26–FY29 [1][18][19][20][36].
- Near-term markers: delivery against Q4 guide (QCT $9.0–$9.6B; QTL $1.25–$1.45B; QCT EBT margin 27–29%) and steady buyback cadence should underpin shares in the next trading sessions [2][1][6][23].
